segment.source: Installing and Uninstalling Custom Compatibility Databases in Compatibility Administrator (Windows 10)
segment.target: Installing and Uninstalling Custom Compatibility Databases in Compatibility Administrator (Windows 10)

segment.source: The Compatibility Administrator tool enables the creation and the use of custom-compatibility and standard-compatibility databases.
segment.target: The Compatibility Administrator tool enables the creation and the use of custom-compatibility and standard-compatibility databases.

segment.source: Installing and Uninstalling Custom Compatibility Databases in Compatibility Administrator
segment.target: Installing and Uninstalling Custom Compatibility Databases in Compatibility Administrator

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows 8.1
segment.target: Windows 8.1

segment.source: Windows 8
segment.target: Windows 8

segment.source: Windows 7
segment.target: Windows 7

segment.source: Windows Server 2012
segment.target: Windows Server 2012

segment.source: Windows Server 2008 R2
segment.target: Windows Server 2008 R2

segment.source: The Compatibility Administrator tool enables the creation and the use of custom-compatibility and standard-compatibility databases.
segment.target: The Compatibility Administrator tool enables the creation and the use of custom-compatibility and standard-compatibility databases.

segment.source: Both the custom databases and the standard databases store the known compatibility fixes, compatibility modes, and AppHelp messages.
segment.target: Both the custom databases and the standard databases store the known compatibility fixes, compatibility modes, and AppHelp messages.

segment.source: They also store the required application-matching information for installation on your local computers.
segment.target: They also store the required application-matching information for installation on your local computers.

segment.source: By default, the Windows® operating system installs a System Application Fix database for use with the Compatibility Administrator.
segment.target: By default, the Windows® operating system installs a System Application Fix database for use with the Compatibility Administrator.

segment.source: This database can be updated through Windows Update, and is stored in the %WINDIR% AppPatch directory.
segment.target: This database can be updated through Windows Update, and is stored in the %WINDIR% AppPatch directory.

segment.source: Your custom databases are automatically stored in the %WINDIR% AppPatchCustom directory and are installed by using the Sdbinst.exe tool provided with the Compatibility Administrator.
segment.target: Your custom databases are automatically stored in the %WINDIR% AppPatchCustom directory and are installed by using the Sdbinst.exe tool provided with the Compatibility Administrator.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: Application Compatibility Toolkit (ACT) installs a 32-bit and a 64-bit version of the Compatibility Administrator tool.
segment.target: Application Compatibility Toolkit (ACT) installs a 32-bit and a 64-bit version of the Compatibility Administrator tool.

segment.source: You must use the 32-bit version to work with custom databases for 32-bit applications and the 64-bit version to work with custom databases for 64-bit applications.
segment.target: You must use the 32-bit version to work with custom databases for 32-bit applications and the 64-bit version to work with custom databases for 64-bit applications.

segment.source: In addition, you must deploy your databases to your organization’s computers before the included fixes will have any effect on the application issue.
segment.target: In addition, you must deploy your databases to your organization’s computers before the included fixes will have any effect on the application issue.

segment.source: For more information about deploying your database, see Using the Sdbinst.exe Command-Line Tool.
segment.target: For more information about deploying your database, see Using the Sdbinst.exe Command-Line Tool.

segment.source: Installing a Custom Database
segment.target: Installing a Custom Database

segment.source: Installing your custom-compatibility database enables you to fix issues with your installed applications.
segment.target: Installing your custom-compatibility database enables you to fix issues with your installed applications.

segment.source: To install a custom database
segment.target: To install a custom database

segment.source: In the left-side pane of Compatibility Administrator, click the custom database to install to your local computers.
segment.target: In the left-side pane of Compatibility Administrator, click the custom database to install to your local computers.

segment.source: On the File menu, click Install.
segment.target: On the File menu, click Install.

segment.source: The Compatibility Administrator installs the database, which appears in the Installed Databases list.
segment.target: The Compatibility Administrator installs the database, which appears in the Installed Databases list.

segment.source: The relationship between your database file and an included application occurs in the registry.
segment.target: The relationship between your database file and an included application occurs in the registry.

segment.source: Every time you start an application, the operating system checks the registry for compatibility-fix information and, if found, retrieves the information from your customized database file.
segment.target: Every time you start an application, the operating system checks the registry for compatibility-fix information and, if found, retrieves the information from your customized database file.

segment.source: Uninstalling a Custom Database
segment.target: Uninstalling a Custom Database

segment.source: When a custom database is no longer necessary, either because the applications are no longer used or because the vendor has provided a fix that resolves the compatibility issues, you can uninstall the custom database.
segment.target: When a custom database is no longer necessary, either because the applications are no longer used or because the vendor has provided a fix that resolves the compatibility issues, you can uninstall the custom database.

segment.source: To uninstall a custom database
segment.target: To uninstall a custom database

segment.source: In the Installed Databases list, which appears in the left-side pane of Compatibility Administrator, click the database to uninstall from your local computers.
segment.target: In the Installed Databases list, which appears in the left-side pane of Compatibility Administrator, click the database to uninstall from your local computers.

segment.source: On the File menu, click Uninstall.
segment.target: On the File menu, click Uninstall.
